We have demonstrated how this works already with the rebellion of the mad count; I strip them of their titles and redistribute them graciously. How is this song or ballad coming along by the way?

Álvaro's face shows grim satisfaction. "Exactly right, Your Majesty. The precedent is already established. The rebels learned what happens - so will anyone else foolish enough to follow their path."

He makes a notation. "Then we prepare accordingly. If either duke refuses the summons, we're prepared to march. The advantage now is that the army hasn't fully disbanded from Granada - we still have forces in the south, the bombards are in Seville, and the crusade treasury can fund operations. A siege against a rebellious duke becomes..." he pauses, searching for the right phrase, "...an administrative matter rather than a crisis."

"And yes - only the title holder faces the ultimate consequences. Their heirs can inherit under new feudal contracts, their soldiers receive mercy if they surrender, their family members aren't punished for the patriarch's folly. The mad count's story proves this: his garrison opened the gates because they knew you'd treat them fairly. That's the model."

Diego nods vigorously. "It also means that when a Crown Marshal arrives at a noble's gate, that noble's own people start calculating. 'Is my lord's tax resistance worth my life? "When good King Juan rode forth in spring,
With banner blessed and holy thing,
The Count of Niebla sealed his gate,
And chose the path of prideful hate.

'Let puppet kings their banners hide!
Though all Castile bend knee to Rome,
I'll die before I leave my home!'

The King approached with measured grace,
No rage upon his youthful face:
'Good count, pay tax and swear your oath,
And ride with me—I'll honor both.

'Your lands stay yours, your title true,
Join holy war as good men do.
The Pope himself has blessed our cause,
Come, serve your kingdom and its laws.'

But madness holds what sense cannot,
The count refused the gracious lot.
'Come take my walls!' he screamed with spite,
And so the King prepared to fight.

Yet when the siege broke stone and gate,
The garrison forestalled cruel fate.
They opened wide the castle door—
'Our lord is mad, we'll fight no more.'

For they had heard how others fared,
Who bent the knee and mercy shared.
At Alcalá, at Loja's wall,
The King showed grace to those who'd fall.

But lone upon the rampart high,
The mad count chose his way to die.
With sword in hand he fought the air,
And saw his phantoms everywhere.

He fell at last, no man his friend,
A prideful, solitary end.

Álvaro looks up. "It continues for several more verses, contrasting the count's fate with Baron Alfonso's peaceful submission, with the fortress commanders who converted and now serve in your army, with Sultan Yusuf's honorable exile. The refrain that repeats is:"

"'Submit to justice, not to shame,
The King gives mercy to those who came.
But pride that will not bend must break,
And lonely death is all it'll take.'"

He sets down the parchment. "Íñigo the Younger plans to perform it at court first - perhaps when we have the next formal gathering. After that, he'll teach it to professional bards and minstrels who travel the kingdom. Within six months, it'll be sung in taverns from Galicia to Granada."

events.summary: Juan visits Isabel in their chambers that afternoon. She confesses her deep fear of dying in childbirth after nearly losing her life delivering Catalina. Juan kneels before her, speaks about the difference between piety and true faith, and prays aloud asking God to grant Isabel courage and strength. She chooses to trust despite her fear, drawing on the evidence that God already saved her and Catalina once. She opens her eyes again, looking at you with raw vulnerability. "Tell me it will be different this time. Tell me I won't die. Even if you can't promise it - even if it's a lie - please tell me."

I hug her tight and press her against me.


God has a plan for this kingdom Isabel. He has a plan and a purpose for you and me. 
When I approach my enemies in the field, I do so with open helmet, trusting in God and I know he will protect me. I know he will protect you as well Isabel.

I know you are pious Isabel, but do you have faith as well? Can you trust in the Lord in this matter as well?

"Faith," she repeats softly. "Not just piety. Faith."

She's quiet for another moment, thinking. When she speaks again, her voice is steadier, though still fragile.

"I pray every day. I attend Mass. I light candles and say the rosary and read the Scriptures. But you're asking me something different, aren't you?" She wipes at her tears with one hand, the other still gripping yours. "You're asking me to trust that God has a purpose even if... even if it's frightening. Even if I can't see how it ends."

She looks toward the window, where the last light is fading. "You rode into battles knowing you might die. You walked up to Granada's gates with just a thousand men, trusting God would protect you. Her hand moves unconsciously to her stomach, where Catalina had grown. "The physicians said she was positioned wrong. They said we'd both die. But we didn't. We're both here."

Fresh tears come, but different now - not just fear, but something else. "Is that what you mean? That God has already shown He has a purpose for me? That He... that He saved us once already?"

She looks at you, searching your face. "Teach me to have that kind of faith, Juan. The kind that trusts even when you're afraid. Because right now, I'm still so afraid. But I want to trust. I want to believe what you believe - that there's a purpose, and that God will see us through it."

She takes a shaky breath. "Will you pray with me? Before... before anything else. Will you ask God together with me for courage? For faith? For His protection?"

I take her face between my hands and look her in the eyes.
